intro: Lupinus argenteus var. heteranthus, commonly known as silver lupine with heteromorphic flowers, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its silvery-gray foliage and distinctive flowers that exhibit dimorphism, with some petals longer than others. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in full sun. Its botanical features include spiny stems and compound leaves with small, oval-shaped leaflets. This variety is often cultivated for its ornamental value and ecological benefits in supporting pollinators.
